thread.title: ESPN criticized for possible Deflategate tweet
thread.title_full: ESPN criticized for possible Deflategate tweet

author: Darren Hartwell
title: ESPN criticized for possible Deflategate tweet
text:
ESPN criticized for possible Deflategate tweet NESN 1 hr ago Darren Hartwell © Spencer Platt/Getty Images ESPN seemingly trolled the Patriots with a Deflategate tweet. ESPN tried to stir the pot Sunday morning, but pretty much just spilled all over itself instead.
AdChoices With the New England Patriots set to take on the Indianapolis Colts on Sunday night in a rematch of the AFC Championship Game that launched the never-ending Deflategate saga, ESPN’s NFL Twitter account decided to send this tweet out early Sunday:
It's NFL Sunday Week 6. GET PUMPED UP. (AP/Rick Osentoski) pic.twitter.com/lwfPh77jW9
— NFL on ESPN (@ESPNNFL) October 18, 2015
Get it, guys? They’re under-inflated footballs! It’s a reference to Deflategate!
Of course, the tweet doesn’t mention the Patriots or Colts, and ESPN probably would tell you the timing is just a coincidence.
But yeah, this isn’t a coincidence. Unfortunately for the network, whose journalistic integrity didn’t exactly shine through during Deflategate, the majority of folks on Twitter weren’t too amused by the over-hashed joke, including a well-known Boston sports fan.
"WE REPORTED THIS STORY WRONG HA HA" RT @ESPNNFL : It's NFL Sunday Week 6. GET PUMPED UP. (AP/Rick Osentoski) pic.twitter.com/NmqWcXGtb0
— Bill Simmons (@BillSimmons) October 18, 2015
Interesting tweet given ESPN’s role in the story http://t.co/1GGwttNz39
— Ben Volin (@BenVolin) October 18, 2015
Now we know. Mark Brunell controls ESPN's twitter. https://t.co/X2ns0cQ3Z6
— Danny Picard (@DannyPicard) October 18, 2015
Lot of credible people work here. But this is a bleeping joke. Journalistic integrity anyone? https://t.co/oCAxoMiI0a
— Michael Giardi (@MikeGiardi) October 18, 2015
@ESPNNFL so mature. How old are you guys?
— Iman (@Imanstah) October 18, 2015
Way to go, ESPN.
Go to MSN Home
